Text.Value: But very well. You are clearly too closed-minded for the ways of Loviatar.

EditorData.NodeContext: A sigh as he dismisses the player and their close-mindedness.

Text.Value: As Vlaakith says: we cannot know pleasure without pain.
Oh, I do believe we are both going to enjoy this.

EditorData.AnimationTags: Player looks and gestures (points) to table level off to the right about 90degrees, as if to choose an item on table few feet away
EditorData.NodeContext: Player has agreed to have the scourge used on him. Abdirak is delighted. Vaguely sexual overtones.

Text.Value: Well, perhaps you'd be interested in finishing what they started?
Leave.
I don't need any 'alleviating', thanks.
Greetings, child. I fear your companion could not fully embrace my penance.

EditorData.InternalNodeContext: This flag is set when the priest hits the player during the penance. So this greeting is handling an edge-case: player starts the penance, get hits one or more, cancels the penance before the end, and then talk to the priest with another character. Keep it simple

Text.Value: Not everyone feels that way.
I'm ready.
I see you are whole once again. Tell me, child - would you care to begin?

EditorData.NodeContext: Player has been healed and is ready to begin penance. Eyes light up - he is excited and looking forward to the beating.
EditorData.logicalname: HP is now OK for penance

Text.Value: Well met, dear child. Would you enjoy some hands-on worship of Loviatar, Maiden of Pain?

EditorData.NodeContext: Player has met Abdirak but not done the penance. Voice low and inviting and familiar.

Text.Value: Take the handaxe and show me your worst.
I'm only passing through.
While I was thrilled to be invited here, I must confess I find the goblins and their methods... crude and primitive.
I'm ready.
I talked with the torturers. Amateurs.
Please. The things they are doing to that man... so crude and primitive.

EditorData.NodeContext: Distates. Like an expert in wine being present with a bottle from Tesco. He loves pain, he just has an issue with the lack of artistery.

Text.Value: Simply face the wall, and we can begin.

EditorData.AnimationTags: Player turning to face wall, PainPriest preparing to provide penance
EditorData.NodeContext: Authorative tone but also a warning. He wants to hurt the player but not badly, and not outside of his realm of control. Safety first!

Text.Value: A pity though. You would know such sweet relief at my hands.

EditorData.NodeContext: sighs at the player's rejections. Sounds charismatic and sensual as he thinks of the beating he would have inflicted on the player.

Text.Value: What do you mean?
...through penance - administered by my skilled hand.

EditorData.NodeContext: Ibid.

Text.Value: Then why are you beating yourself?
I pity them. They've missed out on the true intimacies of pain...
I was invited to teach them some of my... techniques. I live for pain and its intricacies, you see.

EditorData.NodeContext: Discusses eyes light up at the mention of pain but discussing it in an academic sense

Text.Value: All right, why not?
Exactly. And should your friend lack such qualities, that is not their fault.
Ah, you are familiar with the Scourge Mistress? Good. I am simply spreading her message, friend.

EditorData.NodeContext: A smile. The player has realised that he worships an evil goddess. He knows he is likely not going to win this argument on the merits of pain and torture, but he is sincere as he explain how he worships his goddess.

Text.Value: Pain is intimate and loving. But trying to discuss that with these creatures...

EditorData.NodeContext: Irritated in the opening line, but then his eyes light up and he smiles as he discusses PAIN. It is his life's passion and something he is enthusiastic about.

Text.Value: I'm trying to resist my drive to do harm, but it's very difficult.
As long as the story ends in death, it's all the same to me.
I am curious.
I know of your penance - my companion has tried it.
Care to expand your horizons? It will be worth it - you have my word.

EditorData.NodeContext: A smile as he offers to, basically, beat the player. It is a sincere and genuine offer, he believes it will help.

Text.Value: Do not be ashamed, child. What I see in your eyes, in your soul, is only natural.

EditorData.NodeContext: Player has told him to bugger off, basically. Abdirak assumes the player is embarassed, he is sincere - he has seen pain in the player's eyes and wishes to comfort him.

Text.Value: Hahaha. Go on. I have to see this.
But alas, these goblins seem to thrive on the crude and primitive.
Forgive me, but that look in your eyes - something terrible has happened to you.

EditorData.NodeContext: He's looking the player in the eyes and is concerned - he can see the player has been hurt (emotionally) and is worried. This is sincere.

Text.Value: And how would you do that?

EditorData.logicalname: Does know what the penance is

Text.Value: Most excellent! Then I shall speak plainly.
No - I already belong to another.
You see, pain is a loving thing. But trying to explain it to these goblins has proven...

EditorData.NodeContext: Passionate and enthusiastic as he explains. Pain and its infliction is his pride and joy.

Text.Value: I'm not in a gentle mood. Use the dagger.
Why are you so interested?
*This man is of common stock. Only the poorest of men need settle for the spectacle of their own gore.*
To understand pain and its intimacies...
I couldn't agree more.
Oh, I have something exquisite in mind.

EditorData.NodeContext: Player has agreed to the beating/penance. Excited. Sexually charged. Already imaging the pain he is about to inflict.

Text.Value: But alas, they insist on being so primitive.
A pity. You would know such sweet relief at my hands.

EditorData.NodeContext: Sighs. Player has left the conversation without doing any penance. Intimate note to his voice as he thinks of the pain he would have inflicted.

Text.Value: Should you realise you need my assistance, come back. I'll be waiting.
My god is a possessive one - I better refrain.
By all means - let us see what his 'skilled hand' might get up to.
I wouldn't let his 'skilled hand' anywhere near me.
Yes. He's just over there. Between you and I, his claims of mastery over pain are unfounded.

EditorData.InternalNodeContext: Spike is in the same room as the Pain Priest
EditorData.NodeContext: Player has asked who invited him here. It was a goblin who is torturing someone next door. His tone is dismissive. He believes the goblin doesn't know what he's doing.
EditorData.logicalname: Spike is in same room / alive or dead

Text.Value: I'm a contemptible blood-pervert.
A shame - the Mistress of the Night and the Maiden of Pain could have such fun together.
Greetings, child. I've met few aside from goblins here.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: He has paused in beating himself to stand and greet the player.
EditorData.CinematicObjects: Scourge of Loviatar in right hand
EditorData.NodeContext: Player is one of the few non-goblins he's met in this place. Welcomes another for conversation and discussion but there should be something vaguely threatening about him. Charismatic, sexy, and creepy all in one.

Text.Value: Exactly, pain is an intimate thing. It should be delivered with a loving and measured hand.

EditorData.NodeContext: Eyes light up as he discusses pain and his approach to it. This is clearly something he is passionate about and believes in.

Text.Value: Go ahead - I'm sure you're in need of a little penance...

EditorData.NodeContext: Sly smirk. Ribbing the player into engaging in the pain priest's S&M-style ritual.

Text.Value: Now, if you'll excuse me, I should return to my own worship.

EditorData.NodeContext: plans to return to self flagellation. Looking forward to it.

Text.Value: Touch me and you'll lose your hand.
But I understand. Pain is something that requires commitment, wouldn't you say?
I was invited to discuss pain and its intricacies, but even I find these goblins crude and, well - primitive.

EditorData.NodeContext: Distates. Like an expert in wine being present with a bottle from Tesco. He loves pain, he just has an issue with the lack of artistery.

Text.Value: Please let me alleviate this pain.

EditorData.NodeContext: hesitates on the word 'alleiviate'. He believes that the beating he is about to offer will genuinely help. Sincere. Said with a smile.

Text.Value: But wait - you are hurt. Please tend to your wounds before we begin your penance.

EditorData.NodeContext: Player has agreed to do penance but their health is too low. The priest is warning that they must heal first. Genuine and sincere, he doesn't want to hurt them.

Text.Value: Your hide, your choice. Not quite my cup of tea though.

EditorData.NodeContext: emphasis on 'my'

Text.Value: I think I can do without.
I was invited to to teach them. I live for pain and its intricacies, you see, but alas...

EditorData.NodeContext: Discusses eyes light up at the mention of pain but discussing it in an academic sense

Text.Value: Clever man. How did you know?
I thought a follower of Loviatar would approve of pain.
Leave.
True. But isn't that why it's important to try it? To expand your horizons?
And should our pain delight her - should we embrace such a gift - she will grant her most sacred of blessings.

EditorData.NodeContext: Ibid.

Text.Value: Oh, I have something exquisite in mind.

EditorData.NodeContext: Player has agreed to the beating/penance. Excited. Sexually charged. Already imaging the pain he is about to inflict.

Text.Value: Dear child, tell me: would you like to continue your worship of Loviatar, Maiden of Pain?

EditorData.NodeContext: Player started the penance and then cancelled it. Voice low, sexual as he invites them to finish what they started together.

Text.Value: I prefer a fresh canvas.

EditorData.NodeContext: A smile as he says this - vaguely sexual overtones.

Text.Value: You know the Maiden of Pain? How refreshing. But there is more to us than that.

EditorData.NodeContext: Eyes light up as he discusses pain. Considers pain and its intimacies a form of therapy and even art, but he knows that not everyone will feel that way about Pain, or his Goddess, Loviatar.

Text.Value: Hah. I realise this looks strange, but I assure you, it is a most intimate form of worship.

EditorData.NodeContext: The player has pointed out that he is beating himself bloody. He smiles, his eyes lighting up as he begins to explain. He believes in what he is doing.

Text.Value: A most excellent choice.

EditorData.AnimationTags: Player looks and gestures (points) to table level off to the right about 90degrees, as if to choose an item on table few feet away
EditorData.NodeContext: Player has pointed at another additional weapon. Excited and delighted at the thought of using them on the player. Vaguely sexual overtones.

Text.Value: Quite right. I was invited to teach them. I live for pain and its intricacies, you see.

EditorData.NodeContext: Discusses eyes light up at the mention of pain but discussing it in an academic sense

Text.Value: I showed them what a master can do.
But trying to discuss such subtleties with these creatures is simply...

EditorData.NodeContext: Slightly irritated, the goblins have fobbed him off and he's been left to his own painful devices.

Text.Value: Leave.
What's a follower of the Maiden of Pain doing here?
I'm interested in this penance.
I often feel I like raw pain too much. It scares me.
The Mistress would approve. Indicate which instrument calls to you, and let us put it to work.
I thought you would prove interesting... I guess I was mistaken.

EditorData.NodeContext: Sighs. Player has left the conversation without doing any penance. Intimate note to his voice as he thinks of the pain he would have inflicted.

Text.Value: That's none of your concern.
Yes. One who claims to be a master of pain. Tch.

EditorData.NodeContext: Player has asked who invited him here. It was a goblin who is torturing someone next door. His tone is dismissive. He believes the goblin doesn't know what he's doing.

Text.Value: Ah, but of course!
All right, why not?
You mean the one they are torturing?
If you would permit it, I can show you first-hand.

EditorData.NodeContext: He is offering to beat the player with a weapon of choice, This is a sincere and genuine offer, He believes in what he is doing and that it will, ultimately, help the player.

Text.Value: Pity. You do not understand the gift you refuse.

EditorData.NodeContext: Sigh and a shrug at the player's refusal of his penance.

Text.Value: You know the value of suffering. Prepare for the coming pain.
My - an eager student indeed. Those are advanced devotions.

EditorData.AnimationTags: Player looks and gestures (points) to table level off to the right about 90degrees, as if to choose an item on table few feet away

EditorData.InternalNodeContext: A player with the CLERIC or PALADIN tag will have this flag set alreay before starting the dialog, so they bypass the passive check

Text.Value: Unfortunate. Loviatar is always happy to share her pleasures.
Because I see those same eyes when I look in the mirror, dear one.

EditorData.NodeContext: Player has asked how he knew something terrible had happened them. Abdirak sadly replies. He is think of his own traumatic past, which ultimately led him to turn to Loviatar as a way coping with the trauma.

Text.Value: Dear child, I told you - take care of those wounds, and we will begin your penance.

EditorData.NodeContext: Player has tried to come to him for penance but is still wounded. Tone gently chiding, as if speaking to a child.
EditorData.logicalname: Still too low HP for penance

Text.Value: Is that a promise?

EditorData.NodeContext: Player has threatened him with physical violence. He is delighted. Almost winks as he says this.

Text.Value: We've all suffered in these dark times. It is little wonder you bear scars of pain and anguish.

EditorData.NodeContext: He is trying to comfort and connect with the player.

Text.Value: My work can grant peace and serenity - the likes of which few experience. It will be worth it - I promise.
I saw your book. I'd like to try some of those techniques.
If you would permit it, I can show you first-hand.

EditorData.NodeContext: Ibid.

Text.Value: I've no interest in the teachings of such an evil goddess.
Pity. You do not understand the gift you refuse.

EditorData.NodeContext: Sigh and a shrug at the player's refusal of his penance.

Text.Value: Leave.
The gentleman being held next door. My acquaintance is working on him, I believe.
Well - the Maiden of Pain, Loviatar, teaches us that pain is a most powerful and sacred sensation.

EditorData.NodeContext: Explaining about his goddes Loviatar. Sincere. Believes pain is a beautiful thing. Voice more sexy than creepy.

Text.Value: Ah, are you also here to assist with the prisoner?

EditorData.NodeContext: Ibid

Text.Value: Pain should be intimate and loving - not violent and brutish. Alas, he...

EditorData.InternalNodeContext: Spike is alive, so the Pain Priest can be a bit more subtle when talking about him; just for flavour, Spike doesn't really hear the dialog

Text.Value: What prisoner?
I must see this. Don't you dare say no.

EditorData.NodeContext: Excited to see your companion beaten bloody by a flaggellant priest.

Text.Value: I'll have what you're having.
Would you care experience it first-hand? To know peace and serenity, the likes of which few experience?
Prepare for the coming pain.
I feel an endless nausea, that only goes away when I'm killing.
You have refused the gift of penance, dear one. I will waste no more time asking you.
I saw your book. Let me try some of those techniques.
No - Shar has already claimed me.
Who invited you? A goblin?
Both Loviatar and I are interested in how you handle pain, dear one.

EditorData.NodeContext: Authorative tone but also a warning. He wants to hurt the player but not badly, and not outside of his realm of control. Safety first!

Text.Value: I think I can do without.
It's appalling.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext:
He gestures to the table, where a selection of weapons lays ready. The priest should look very sincere in this scene. He genuinely 
thinks he's helping you.

Text.Value: *You recognise the scourge - this man is a follower of Loviatar, goddess of pain.*
Your tastes must turn to the exotic, if you would stop here by choice.
Or claimed, rather. Pain should be intimate and loving - not violent and brutish. Perhaps in death he...
Yes, we worship her through pain - often our own. But it is an intimate and loving thing and one we offer up.
Pain is pain, dear one. It is above 'good' and 'evil'.

EditorData.NodeContext: Player has told him that his goddess is evil and that he wants to part in this practice. His argument about pain is sincere, he sees it as neither good nor evil, simply as proof that we are alive - and that is worth worshipping and experiencing.

Text.Value: I worship her through pain - usually my own. But I have a skilled hand when it comes to its infliction.

EditorData.NodeContext: Ibid.

Text.Value: And should you delight her, you will most assuredly receive her gracious blessing - trust me.
As the Maiden of Pain, the goddess Loviatar, teaches us...

EditorData.NodeContext: Player has asked about the 'penance' Abdirak has suggested. Explaining about his goddes Loviatar. Sincere. Believes pain is a beautiful thing. Voice more sexy than creepy.

Text.Value: Pain without purpose is a terrible thing, wouldn't you agree?

EditorData.NodeContext: No horror in his voice. Discussing it like an intellectual pursuit. It is not the violence he takes issue with, it is the fact that they do it simply for fun.

Synopsis:
Father Abdirak is a follower of Loviatar, a goddess that thrives on inflicting pain on others. He is indulging in some private 'worship' (self flagellation). He offers to help alleviate the player's pain by giving them 'penance' - i.e, beating them. 
Loviatar = loh-VEE-a-tar. He is a young and charismatic preacher with a threatening edge.
